TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

On DATE the applicant was arrested and taken into custody by the Bursa police in connection with an investigation into the activities of the ORG ( Partiya PERSON – Workers’ ORG ) . He was transferred immediately to the premises of the GPE security police , the authority in charge of the investigation . He was questioned until DATE , when he signed a statement and admitted carrying out activities within the organisation in question .

On DATE the applicant was interviewed by the GPE public prosecutor and subsequently by a magistrate , partly confirming on both occasions the statements he had made to the police . The magistrate made an order for the applicant ’s pre - trial detention . He was accordingly transferred to Nazilli E - type Prison in the ORG district .

On DATE the public prosecutor attached to ORG ( “ the public prosecutor ” , “ the ORG ” ) charged the applicant and CARDINAL others with being a member of and assisting the ORG . He sought the application of LAW and CARDINAL of LAW and LAW no . ORG ) .
On DATE the trial began in ORG in the case , registered as no . CARDINAL . The first hearing was devoted to purely procedural matters .

The second hearing was held on DATE in the absence of the defendants – including the applicant – who had informed the court in writing that they would not be appearing in protest against the arrest of Mr A. ORG , the ORG leader . However , the applicant ’s counsel , Mr GPE , submitted that his client had acted against his will out of solidarity with his fellow detainees . The trial judges confined themselves to reading out the indictment and checking that the lawyers present had been duly authorised .

At a hearing on DATE in case no . CARDINAL the applicant and his counsel lodged defence pleadings which were read out and added to the file . The judges then asked the defendants to comment on the various statements taken during the preliminary investigation . The applicant said that he confirmed only the statements he had made in the context of his defence pleadings .
Having regard to all these considerations , the judges decided to join the case in question to case no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , which was pending before the same bench .
DATE ORG resumed its examination of the joined case no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . The applicant again appeared with his counsel .

At that hearing , in which a military judge took part , ORG took note of the joinder of case no . CARDINAL and of the contents of the file in that case . The judges subsequently informed the new defendants of all the procedural steps taken previously and read out the documents in the file to the parties , including earlier statements by some of the applicant ’s fellow defendants implicating him .

The applicant and his counsel challenged all the prosecution evidence in case no . DATE , including the statements in question , and , as to the merits , submitted their written pleadings , requesting the judges to endorse them . The pleadings were added to the file . No other decisive steps were taken DATE .

On DATE Article CARDINAL of the LAW was amended with the effect that military judges were barred from sitting as members of national security courts . Further to the consequent amendments made to ORG on DATE , the military judge on the bench of ORG was replaced by a civilian judge .

The first hearing in which the new judge took part was held on DATE and was attended by the applicant and his counsel . It began with the reading out of all the records of the previous hearings . As Mr GPE stated that he had nothing to add at that stage of the proceedings , no steps were taken in respect of the applicant . The next hearing was scheduled for DATE .

On DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of being a member of the ORG and sentenced him to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . It held that although he had retracted all the statements which the police and the public prosecutor had taken from him , the confessions resulting from his pleadings filed on DATE were sufficient to establish that he had indeed been a member of the ORG .
The applicant appealed on points of law . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the impugned judgment .

Before DATE section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL provided that CARDINAL of the CARDINAL judges sitting in national security courts had to be a military judge ( for the legislation in force at the time , see GPE v. GPE , judgment of DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL-IV , pp . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL ) .

Following the entry into force of Law no . CARDINAL on the above - mentioned date , military judges were no longer allowed to sit in the national security courts , which were eventually abolished by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE .
